triples.name: Distribution of fitness effects
triples.relevance: The paper proposes a novel characterization of how the distribution of fitness effects of mutations changes dynamically during long-term bacterial evolution.

triples.name: Mutation
triples.relevance: The paper quantifies fitness effects of mutations as mutations are the fundamental source of genetic variation that drives evolution.

triples.name: Fitness (biology)
triples.relevance: The paper measures fitness effects of mutations, examining how individual reproductive success is altered by genetic changes.

triples.name: Evolution
triples.relevance: The paper studies bacterial evolution across 50,000 generations to understand how fitness effects of mutations change during adaptation.

triples.name: Escherichia coli
triples.relevance: E. coli is the model organism used throughout the paper to conduct long-term evolution experiments and measure mutational effects.

triples.name: Insertional mutagenesis
triples.relevance: The paper quantifies fitness effects specifically of insertion mutations, using this type of mutagenesis as the experimental approach.

triples.name: Loss-of-function mutation
triples.relevance: Loss-of-function mutations are identified as key targets of selection and are predictable drivers of beneficial effects during evolution.

triples.name: Essential gene
triples.relevance: Changes in gene essentiality are analyzed as a microscopic mechanism explaining how fitness effects of mutations vary over evolutionary time.

triples.name: Structural variation
triples.relevance: Structural variation is examined as a potential partial explanation for changes in gene essentiality during the evolution experiment.
